boardgame.name: Boron-Vademecum
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb

"We all die. Only Boron knows when your hour has come."

-Excerpt from the Black Book

What are the differences between the two Boron churches? Which saints does the Punin rite know and which are venerated in Al'Anfa? How exactly are liturgies performed in the Church of the Silent Liturgies? Which prayers, chorales and rituals are celebrated in everyday temple life? What do the God of Death and his consecrated ones think of undead revenants? And what can my hero expect when, at the end of his life, he is picked up by the Golgari raven?

The Boron Vademecum offers a variety of Aventurian background material on the Church of the Inescapable and its Consecrated. Besides stories about saints and talismans of the Boron Church, this booklet also contains a detailed description of prayers, rituals and liturgies. Aventurian sources make it possible to experience the work of both great churches at the console. They are supplemented by texts on ideals of the religious community, the Order of the Boron Church as well as valuable information for players and masters on the role-playing representation of a Boron consecrated man and his involvement in the game.

This game help is suitable for masters and players of all experience levels.


Klappentext

"Wir alle sterben. Allein Boron weiß, wann deine Stunde gekommen ist.“

-Auszug aus dem Schwarzen Buch

Was sind die Unterschiede zwischen den beiden Boronkirchen? Welche Heiligen kennt der Puniner Ritus und welche verehrt man in Al'Anfa? Wie genau werden in der Kirche des Schweigsamen Liturgien gewirkt? Welche Gebete, Choräle und Rituale werden im Tempelalltag zelebriert? Wie stehen der Gott des Todes und seine Geweihten zu untoten Wiedergängern? Und was kann mein Held erwarten, wenn er am Ende seines Lebens vom Seelenraben Golgari abgeholt wird?

Das Boron-Vademecum bietet vielerlei aventurisches Hintergrundmaterial über die Kirche des Unausweichliche und seiner Geweihten. Neben Geschichten über Heilige und Talismane der Boronkirche enthält dieses Büchlein auch eine ausführliche Darstellung von Gebeten, Ritualen und Liturgien. Aventurische Quellen machen das Wirken beider großer Kirchen am Spieltisch erfahrbar. Ergänzt werden sie um Texte zu Idealen der Glaubensgemeinschaft, den Orden der Boronkirche sowie wertvolle Hinweise für Spieler und Meister zur rollenspielerischen Darstellung eines Borongeweihten und seine Einbindung ins Spiel.

Diese Spielhilfe ist für Meister und Spieler aller Erfahrungsstufen geeignet.

boardgame.name: Secrets of the Chi War
Мак и Лотос
boardgame.description:
From the PDF:

Factions of chi warriors battle through the Netherworld and across four junctures in time and space for dominance. Feng Shui sites, each one a nexus of world-changing power, topple and fall. Critical shifts unleash cross-time changes hitherto unknown to humanity. Terrible villains, ruthless dictators, conspiring agents, and abominations of unspeakable origin gather to fight for victory in this endless war.

Revealed here for the first time are new secrets of this tireless conflict, from battle zones in each juncture to pop-up junctures open only for a short time — long enough to serve as the front lines of the Chi War.

Expanding on material contained within the Feng Shui 2 core rulebook, Secrets of the Chi War unleashes even more potent lore for use in your games, including a full-length adventure set in Japan!

Visit the Ancient, Past, Modern, and Future Junctures, and learn the secrets of the Netherworld
Blow up Chang’an, Canton, Seoul, Tokyo, Ape City, the Gene Zone, or the Pagodas
Hurtle through the temporary Netherworld portals to the time of the warring states, the swinging 1960s, the funky 70s, the pastel-tinted 80s, or even the far distant past, where dinosaurs roam
Fight through the streets of Tokyo in the adventure The Lotus and the Poppy


Join contributors from across the game publishing industry in ushering in a new era... or relive eras now lost to history and the machinations of Chi Warriors past and present!

Join us in the Secrets of the Chi War!

boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Dirty Rotten Rats!

Weary and thirsty, your dig team arrives in the tiny village of Rust Haven just in time to save the day! Beasts have attacked the village and while the militia chases them off, Black Scavenger, an ambitious bipedal rat mercenary, has escaped from the jail. He and with his thugs fled into the ruins beneath the community! With Rust Haven’s best fighters out in the wastes, the people of the settlement need you to go into the ancient depths and bring the villain, Black Scavenger, to justice, dead or alive.

What horrors, curiosities and artifacts your team will find below the earth are unknown, but this is what you live for. You are excavators and post-apocalyptic heroes.

boardgame.name: Red Shift Lite
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Red Shift Lite is a quick start / fast play document to introduce players to the full Red Shift game. Most of the document focuses on character creation.

In the game, players begin with Character Points which are spent to purchase things during (and after) character creation. Most games will play with 100-150 Character Points.

Characters first buy Scores in the fifteen Attributes and then select a Race which will limit or enable future options. Red Shift Lite supports only two races: Human and Rhyrha. Characters next select a Profession which is somewhat like a "light-weight" class. Professions have minimum Attribute requirements and also provide Skills, possible bonuses, and bonus equipment. Characters have Talents and Advantages, as well as Disadvantages. Some characters also have Psionics; some Professions require Psionic ability for entry. Combat utilizes a dice pool comparison to a target number and supports damage and other familiar aspects of role-playing games.

boardgame.name: Red Shift (2nd Edition)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Red Shift is a complete science-fiction roleplaying game system. It uses the Destiny Engine, a game engine that is used for all of Grendel Roleplaying’s core games. This allows you to use the characters you create in many different settings. Red Shift is designed to be playable by those who have never played a roleplaying game before, and yet still have the complexity that experienced players desire.

The basic concept of Red Shift is that after approximately nine hundred years of exploration, colonization, and war, mankind has spread out into all of the star systems near Earth. The great colony ships set out to find new and better worlds than our poor Earth, and hopefully not to make the same mistake of destroying the ecosystem with pollution and war. Many of them were lost among the unforgiving stars.

User summary:

Characters have Talents and Advantages, as well as Disadvantages. Some characters also have Psionics; some Professions require Psionic ability for entry.

boardgame.name: Okhrana
boardgame.description:
From the document:

In Okhrana, no one person controls the game; everybody round the table gets the chance to input. Sometimes an individual will play the role of their protagonist, an émigré revolutionary who acts against the Czarist regime. Sometimes they will be asked to play the character of an antagonist, a member of the Okhrana, one of their informers, a spy or an ally in the French police, the Surete Generale.

Each player must create a protagonist for themselves. The protagonist is an individual upon whom a story will focus. That story is told in the form of six scenes, with the story of each protagonist being told, scene by scene, in order.

User summary:

The game originally was created in 24 hours as a 24-hour RPG contest entry.

boardgame.name: Reel Adventures
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Reel Adventures presents a system that attempt to recreate a cinematic style role-playing game with fast action and structured narrative arc. The system does not us a Game Master, instead cycling similar responsibilities among all players. The game is atypical in the amount of planning and setup that is needed before play begins. The group generates a "Reel Script" that features a synopsis and four "Acts" that guide the session and form the narrative arc. Play then proceeds based largely upon shared narrative development. Characters have three Abilities (Action, Emotion, Brains) that determine a dice pool for contested action resolution. The mechanic is a simple die pool roll vs. die pool roll with the highest total winning. The remainder of character generations focuses on methods to maintain a rapidly-paced narrative.

The game was provided as three downloadable PDF files--a one-page character sheet, a three-page Reel Script, and a twenty-one page rules document.

boardgame.name: A Sundered World
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

As the cathedral drifts before the angel gate the priests begin chanting prayers, beseeching it to open a path so that they may once again begin the Golden Pilgrimage.

A ship loaded with firewater and other contraband from the City of Brass drifts silently through the Deep Astral, hoping to evade border islands...and whatever lurks in the darkness.

As a kytheran raiding fleet swiftly approaches, the soldiers of a dwarven multi-fort load elemental cores into an array of fire lances.

Thoughtform trembling with nervousness in front of so many enlightened Astral weavers, a t’pual battlemind begins its graduating shape-kata exam.

A mining vessel launches a series of towing chains into a stabilized earth mote. They begin to reel it in, hoping it won’t fluctuate before they can extract usable ore to process later.

The consuming darkness crawls towards the cold, pale spires of the elven city Astrazalian. Most of the inhabitants retreat behind closed doors: only the White Owls, nobility and the ignorant dare tread outside before it passes.

A Sundered World is a fantastic, kind of gonzo campaign setting for Dungeon World. It takes place in the shattered remnants of the worlds, which were ravaged during a cosmic war between the gods and primordials (which wiped them all out in the process). It includes:

Ten races, each with their own race moves, to better allow you to determine how much your race affects you (and serve as a foundation in case you want to flesh out an entire racial class). There's also guidelines and suggestions for using them in "default" Dungeon World games.
Six new classes.
New weapons, armor, dungeon gear (including poisons), services, transport options, hireling skills, buildings, and magic items.
Materials to further customize your weapons and armor: bind a wind spirit to your spear so that it flies further, shape a shield out of black ice, or don sturdy-yet-weightless armor shaped from raw astral essence.
Ships, both magical and mundane, to help you get around the Remnants, Maelstrom, and the darker regions beyond. There's ship-specific moves, plenty of example ships to choose from, and a section to help you build an entirely custom ship of your own design.
World moves for drifting through the astral, willing objects into existence using astral essence, lingering on as a ghost when you die, and more.
Eleven new monster settings, detailing glorious-yet-terrifying angels, sinister devils, cold, emotionless machines from the pre-Sundering era, spirits that managed to survive the Sundering, and strange beasts that were changed during the Sundering, or managed to adapt.
Six varied example campaign and adventure fronts to get you started.

boardgame.name: Quissama
boardgame.description:
Rio de Janeiro, 1868. Quissama is a fugitive slave from guaiamum malta who counts on English detective Woodruff to help him find Bernardina, his missing mother. At the same time, he needs to run from Alemão and his malta, who wants to capture him. Araújo wants to make his business prosper, but Alencar is eyeing the political influence. In the court, the Princess wants to set slaves freed, while the Emperor uses his power as he pleases. In the squares, you will face the capoeira fighting between Nagoas and Guaiamuns, which divide the Rio de Janeiro at the time. Choose your characters and take part in this plot!

How to play
Draw, combine and use your cards to establish your territory in Rio de Janeiro, 1868. Place your meeples and prosper thanks to coins that will help open trades, free slaves and employ capoeiras. With some card combinations, get the right to choose a character. Use your skills and reach your goal to win the match. But be careful with your opponents! They can cause malta attacks against your territory, deploy your ministers or steal the characters you worked hard to win. Go through all scandals and the power of money and be the first to reach one of your characters' goal!

boardgame.name: Universal Adventures Adventure Module FG1: The Forgotten Graveyard
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Face the horrors of the Forgotten Graveyard!

The crumbling necropolis has always been a dangerous place, crawling with undead and occasionally attracting the most unsavory characters. Word has reached the commander of the Border Patrol, though, that their may be some new evil afoot within the haunted depths of the Forgotten Graveyard. Can your characters survive long enough to find out what it is?

Universal Adventures The Forgotten Graveyard is a new Adventure Module. Set north of the town of Ravenor along the western edge of Greyshroud Ridge, you can combine the adventure with Expedition to Erathor and the expansion pack, Greyshroud Ridge, to create an overland journey. The Adventure Module includes a new Adventure Record, 9 Adventure cards, 9 Encounter cards, 9 Event cards, 9 Search cards, 18 Treasure cards, 9 Dark Chasm cards, 9 Winged Statue cards, 9 Blackstone Tomb cards and 9 Infernex cards. In addition, The Forgotten Graveyard can be used as the surface area for additional adventures set beneath the necropolis.

Gather your heroes and enter the depths of the Forgotten Graveyard, if you dare. Suitable for use with any fantasy role playing game, The Forgotten Graveyard can be played solo or with a group, with or without a GM. The adventure is highly re-playable and compatible with other Universal Adventures cards. In addition, you can combine the cards with other cards from the series, or cards from other Universal Adventures products, to create your own adventures.

The Adventure Module is a new, simple way to play fantasy adventures. The organization and presentation of the adventures allows for quick setup, quick play and gives you the ability to focus on the action and “story” while leaving you the option to include tactical action and combat if you desire. Enter a new and exciting world of adventure, full of wonder and surprises.

From publisher blurb:

Gruesome is Good

Dragons are incredibly dangerous threats, but their very popularity robs them of suspense. They fly, they have breath weapons, and you don’t want to get caught next to one when it full attacks.

The idea behind gruesome dragons is to make them more interesting for players and GMs. Rather than face yet another color-coded dragon encounter, the players find themselves facing a plague dragon capable of ending civilizations, or skittering draconic ambush predators obsessed with building the perfect adventurer trap. Gruesome dragons have uncanny appearances, smells, and sounds that makes them more frightening to even veteran characters.

From Yaah! magazine #4 published by Flying Pig Games:

Poland Strikes! is a standalone module in the Sticks and Stones series. The first entry, published by Flying Pig's sister company Tiny Battle Publishing, saw Soviets and Yankees fighting over precious land in Germany in post-nuclear 1987. While the USSR is distracted by all of this, Poland decides to settle the score with Hungary after years of escalating tensions along the border. With three scenarios and 88 counters gorgeously illustrated by wunderkind Christian Sperling (Neuschwabenland), it's a cold-war-goes-hot tactical combat game by the undisputed master of the genre.

Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

boardgame.name: Returner Final Fantasy Role Playing Game Lite Version
boardgame.description:
Based upon the Returner FFRPG V2.0

From the foreword:

It's been discussed many times, particularly from newer people, about having a version of the Returner FFRPG that is possible to print out without hacking down the Amazon Rain Forest. After printing out three versions of the FFRPG (an earlier version, 1.2, and now 2.0), a Lite Version just might be necessary. Keep in mind that this is, by no means, a substitute for the complete HTML and Word versions of the FFRPG. Don't get me wrong: I'm not going to try and compress 200 or so pages into about 30. This is basically a quick reference guide for those who don't want to search through 200 pages of the complete version just to, say, find out the MDC progression of a Ranger. This can also be dubbed The FFRPG for Dummies, because it explains the system in a nutshell so newer FFRPG gamers and newer gamers in general can jump right in. In other words, this is the meat and potatoes.

boardgame.name: Monster Construction System
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Throughout the Final Fantasy series, monsters and the villains often played a role as equally important as that of the heroes themselves. What would Final Fantasy VI be without the antics of Kefka and Ultros if they didn't try getting into the Returner's way at every possible chance? The Monster Construction System gives gamemasters the chance to create their own memorable monsters to sick on their players - from gentle Rabites to fearsome dragons of the worst kind. If you have an idea for it, the Monster Construction System can help make it a reality.

boardgame.name: Vehicle Manual
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

In most Final Fantasy games, gaining access to a vehicle (normally an airship) is an important step in the game. It allows the player to go to places where they were previously unable to go on by foot, chocobo, or, if it was available in the game, a boat. Normally a vehicle doesn’t really do much in the Final Fantasy games else.

But this Vehicle Manual does things differently.

Inspired by games such as Skies of Arcadia and Xenogears, the Vehicle Manual allows players or gamemasters to construct nearly any type of vehiclebe it a tank, mecha, submarine, airship, or spaceshipfor the Returner Final Fantasy RPG system. These vehicles can then be used to fight with other similar vehicles, which is what this sourcebook was created for. The Vehicle Manual includes comprehensive rules for vehicle creation, combat, equipment, enemy vehicles, and even gamemaster advice for campaigns where the game centers on the use of vehicles nearly as much as it does around the characters themselves.

boardgame.name: Final Fantasy Roleplaying Game (2nd Edition)
Returner Final Fantasy Roleplaying Game (2nd Edition)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

In 1990, the first Final Fantasy game saw an American release and in the eleven years since, the Final Fantasy has remained one of the best selling role-playing games for each of the console game systems that it has graced. This pen & paper roleplaying game, the Returner Final Fantasy RPG (often abbreviated as Returner FFRPG or just FFRPG), was designed to emulate the popular game series and similar titles from the "SNES era" such as Secret of Mana and Chrono Trigger. The Introduction includes the editor’s words of wisdom: From the Mouth of a Madman, the revision history that lists all the important changes made, a brief explanation on what a roleplaying game is, how to roll dice ("the fine art of chugging dice"), and the glossary of Final Fantasy RPG terminology.

boardgame.name: SeeD
boardgame.description:
User summary:

SeeD is a difficult rules set to summarize because of its modular design; character generation, for example, can follow one of six major methodologies: Class, Crystal, License, Job, Eidolon, or Limit Break. The method selected will depend upon the video game that is begin emulated as the basis of the table-top role-playing game. The Skill system is similarly modular, presenting three major systems: Talent, Reel, and Fortune. Inventory and outfitting will follow either: Equipment, Remodeling, or Bare. Finally, any of these various modules may be combined with any other combination to form a final basis of "pick and use" components that are selected primarily because they are the closest match to the emulated video game.

Generally, action resolution is percentile based and features a target number called the "Chance of Success". Players then roll percentiles and attempt to "roll under" the target. Depending upon which system(s) are being utilized, there are few to many modifiers that may apply.

The principle design goals of the system-of-systems are to 1) allow for the close emulation of nearly any video game roleplaying experience, and 2) present a fast-paced "video game" like playing experience.

boardgame.name: SeeD 2
boardgame.description:
User summary:

SeeD 2 is an evolution from SeeD, not a 2nd Edition. Instead of being completely modular, the Seed 2 implementation seeks standardization of rules which are designed for emulation of video games. In almost all respects, it is a more traditional generic, universal system than SeeD.

In SeeD 2, characters have six Attributes (Attack, Magic, Will, Vitality, Stamina, and Luck. Each Attribute is given a 6 during character creation and the player distributes into them 12 more points by fiat, to a maximum score of 10. Hit Points and Movement Points are then derived by formula. Characters begin play with one weapon and one armor. Characters select a Class (from a list of 12), but Class is much less structured than defined in the SeeD Class module. Characters may select Skills from a Class list; most Skills have special actions associated with them. The combat system offers various maneuvers during a round, including Attack. SeeD 2 utilizes a standard D100 roll against a target "Chance of Success" that is determined based on difficulty and modifiers. Players attempt to "roll under" the target.

boardgame.name: Denmark (fan expansion for Ticket to Ride)
boardgame.description:
This map is an unofficial Fan made expansion. Symbols & Graphics Copyright © 2004-2015 Days of Wonder, Inc. Produced with permission of Days of Wonder, for non-commercial use only.

This follows the principles of the basic Ticket to Ride game on a special board with special cards and rules. The object of the game is to gain the most points by travelling various routes and outwitting other players. You will need the train pieces and the train cards from either the US or Europe base games (or you can buy them from the Days of Wonder shop. You can use stations if you wish.

There is an extra set of cards for the "cities", each with a value to be earned by visiting that "city". These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules. Some of the cards give you extra facilities to complete your tickets. There are also up to 9 bonuses for the end-of-game scoring.

The main new rule is the option to discard 5 cards and pick up 5 new ones, as your turn. This is very useful if you are desperate for engines or a particular colour card. You can also call time when your wagon stock reaches 3, if you want, giving you the advantage of stopping other players completing tickets.

boardgame.name: Frogabout boardgame
boardgame.description:
A fascinating educational game that tells you all about the ecology and life history of our extraordinary Australian frogs (description from the back of the game board)

The game is a roll and move. On about every third space there are instructions to follow (eg "Hot weather. Have a rest. Miss a turn.", "Jump for joy. You have found a mate already. Advance to 'Egg-laying lilypad.'", "DANGER You are eaten by a yabbie. Return to start.").

Sometimes the instructions are to take a "Tadpole" or a "Frog" card. These cards have a similar range of penalties and benefits as the board spaces with instructions. The frog cards are much larger than the tadpole cards, in full colour and include some factual information about frogs on them. A couple require the player to imitate a frog's call (described on the card) to receive the benefit.

There are two places where players get a choice of paths but other than that there is no choice in movement.

boardgame.name: Who Am I? Music Edition
boardgame.description: Party quiz game about (mainly) pop stars. Each of the 55 large format (11.5 x 8 cm) cards gives five facts about a particular pop star. A player rolls a dice and is read the clue that corresponds to the number rolled. If they correctly identify the pop star, they win the card. The sixth fact on each card is the name of the pop star, so if they roll a 6 they automatically win the card. The game is won by the first player to win 5 cards. There are 9 special power cards that allow, for example, an extra clue or the opportunity to 'steal' a card. These are kept by the 'reader' who picks them up.

boardgame.name: Mars (fan expansion for Ticket to Ride)
boardgame.description:
This map is an unofficial Fan made expansion. Symbols & Graphics Copyright © 2004-2015 Days of Wonder, Inc. Produced with permission of Days of Wonder, for non-commercial use only.

This follows the principles of the basic Ticket to Ride game on a special board with special cards and rules. The object of the game is to gain the most points by travelling various routes and outwitting other players. You will need the train pieces and the train cards from either the US or Europe base games (or you can buy them from the Days of Wonder shop. You can use stations if you wish.

There is an extra set of cards for the "cities", each with a value to be earned by visiting that "city". These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules. Some of the cards give you extra facilities to complete your tickets. There are also up to 9 bonuses for the end-of-game scoring.

The main new rule is the option to discard 5 cards and pick up 5 new ones, as your turn. This is very useful if you are desperate for engines or a particular colour card. You can also call time when your wagon stock reaches 3, if you want, giving you the advantage of stopping other players completing tickets.

boardgame.description:
Reapers is a role-playing game for 3-8 people, but it is recommended for groups of 4-5 players. This game is entirely GMless and relies heavily on narration and cooperation between players. All you need to play is a deck of tarot cards (or regular playing cards, jokers removed) and a notecard for each player to write down information about their character.

You and your friends play Reapers: individuals who have discovered that they possess a unique ability to sense each other’s emotional states and help one another by projecting their own skills or guidance onto another Reaper in need. You will narrate a story of individuals facing their own obstacles and fears, and, together, you will find that the strength and support of your friends can help you overcome anything.

boardgame.name: Quality Street Monopoly
boardgame.description:
This is a card game, a variation of the English game Pairs (known as Memo or Memory in Europe) but has unique twists on that type of game. The game was given away in Quality Street boxes of chocolates in 2005.

Object of the game: To finish with property worth more than any other player.

The playing cards are placed at random face down on the table. Each player should also start the game with 7 Quality Street sweets!

Starting with the youngest, the players turn over two cards. If the property on the two cards is identical, the player keeps the cards and turns over two others. When two cards which do not match are revealed, they are turned over face down again, and the player’s turn is over.

Hidden in the playing cards are a number of ‘Community Chest’ and ‘Chance’ cards. If revealed, the player accepts their reward or fine, and if it is the first card turned over, that player still turns over a second card as part of their turn. These cards are removed from the table once revealed.

There is one ‘Go to Jail’ card. If this is revealed that player’s turn is over (even if it is the first card turned), and they must miss their next turn. Unlike the Chance and Community Chest cards, this card stays on the table, so you are wise to remember where it is!

The cards have a value on them (related to real values on a traditional English Monopoly board). So it is not the one with the most cards who wins, it is the one with the highest value of cards that wins.

boardgame.name: My Big World: Europe
boardgame.description:
A fun and simple geo-themed game, where players put their tokens on a map, trying to be the nearest from the monument shown on the card. But beware, i bet you're not on the good place !

First, players draw a card from a pile, that displays a monument, a famous building, or anything else related to a specific place, sometimes accompanied by a flag.

The players should guess where in Europe this place is. The first player put his meeple where he think the answer is, on the European map/board. The next player take his turn and must do the same.

When all players have placed their markers, the card is turned over, revealing the right position. Now, using the benchmarks along the edges of the map, the players should deduct how far they are distant from the solution. The nearest player from this place score more points. If 2 or more player's markers are on the same position, the token that is under the others scores more points.

Then a new card is revealed. Game ends after 12 cards revealed.

boardgame.name: Kelly Party Surprise
boardgame.description:
It's Kelly's Birthday, but the presents have gotten all mixed up! Help Kelly match the presents to the friends who brought them. This game is part Memory and part set matching.

Includes 20 Friends Cards with the matching present shown in the corner; 20 Gifts for Kelly: 4 yellow stars, 4 pink hearts, 4 blue flowers and 4 purple squares with different gifts inside; 2 Kelly Cards; and instruction sheet.

Cards are dealt out evenly to players. If a player is dealt a Kelly card, she places it face up beside her and is dealt another card so that each player has the same number of Friends Cards.

The presents are turned upside down in the center. Players take turns turning over a present to see if it matches the present on one of the Friends cards she holds. If it does, she shows it to everyone along with the card and sets the two aside. If it does not, she shows the other players what is inside the present and turns it back over. If a player has a Kelly card, she can use it to turn over all the presents of one shape until she finds the present she is looking for. The Kelly card is then turned over and cannot be used again. The winner is the first to find all the presents matching their Friends cards.

A second way to play is to turn the presents upside down in the center and put the rest of the cards in a draw pile. Player turns one card over and tries to find the matching present. If the present matches the player takes the Friends card & present and sets them aside and turns over the next card. If the present does not match, the next player gets to turn over a present and try to match the card, continuing until a player matches the present to the card. If a Kelly card is turned over, the player turns the next Friends card over and uses the Kelly card to help her turn over the presents until she finds a match. Winner is the player with the most matches.

Tilt the balance of power in your favor and hold it until the end of the game, and you win! But beware... These are not mindless minions, but proud and dangerous creatures. Blackguards 2 will stay an SRPG focussing on turn-based, strategic battles with a group of scoundrels as anti-heroes. boardgame.name: Curio Collectors
Kimono
Zooscape
はんか通骨董市
ヘンゼルかグレーテル: Hansel or Gretel
boardgame.description:
The animals have escaped from the zoo, and it's up to the zookeepers to get everyone back in their cages — but lots of things can happen while you're chasing critters...

In Zooscape, originally released as Curio Collectors (はんか通骨董市), you must prove yourself the best zookeeper by rounding up animals worth the most points, but remember that all the animals need enough space in their cage to stay happy! Shove too many in one cage, and they'll be worth almost nothing to you.

In each round, someone deals a line of twelve cards face up on the table; each card depicts an animal (a curio in the original version) along with a point value and a limit. The starting player splits the line in two by choosing a dividing point. Each player holds two cards showing the left or right group, and each player chooses, then simultaneously reveals which group of cards they want. If only one player chooses a side, they take all the cards in that group and add them to their personal tableau. If a side is chosen by more than one player, however, then one of the players who chose it splits that group into two smaller groups, then everyone who originally chose this group secretly votes again for which group they want. This process repeats with each group until either each player has taken some number of cards or groups have been reduced to single cards and two or more players are still voting to take them; in this case, those single cards are placed in a special pile. At the start of a round, the starting player adds a special card to the line-up and whoever wins this card collects all of the animals in this special pile.

Players complete three rounds this way, then score points. If a group of cards has exceeded the limit on it — say, by collecting four cards when the limit is three — then the owner of these cards scores only 1 point per card instead of the point value for each card. Some cards in the game allow you to remove cards from your collection, possibly allowing you to stay under the limit and score more points. You might also start trying not to win cards so as not to spoil the value of what you've already collected. (In Curio Collectors, you would effectively crash the market value for an item by trying to sell too many of them at one time.) Whoever has the most points wins!

Zooscape has also been published as Kimono, with players collecting Japan-related collectibles and cultural objects.

boardgame.name: Sorcerer King
boardgame.description:
A NEW KIND OF FANTASY STRATEGY GAME

Sorcerer King is a new direction for strategy game design, pitting the player against a single overwhelmingly powerful enemy instead of a set of evenly matched factions racing for abstract victory conditions.

Think of the Sorcerer King as the evil mage who already won the last traditional game. He has already conquered the world. His enemies (including you) are scattered, their armies broken and cities torn down. His dark minions have free reign to terrorize the survivors everywhere except a few tiny outposts of civilization (like the one you start in) too insignificant to crush.

EXPANDING YOUR KINGDOM

What do you know, there was another one of those darn cataclysms. It's up to you to rebuild a kingdom that can stand up to the bad guys.

You'll need to clear out monsters and bandits with heroes and armies, then send pioneers to build cities on arable land and outposts to claim outlying resources.

Expanding your kingdom via pioneers is vital, and should be one of your highest priorities.

EXPLORING THE LAND

The landscape is dotted with a random selection of the hundreds of quests in Sorcerer King. Completing them grants you crafting components, lore for researching new spells, new units, magical artifacts, and can even increase or decrease the Doomsday Counter.

If you see something interesting on the map, chances are you should explore it and see what it is. At the very least, you'll probably get a chuckle out of the writing - Chris Bucholz of Cracked.com writes all of our quests, and he's a funny guy.

EXTERMINATING THE MONSTERS

Battles in Sorcerer King are quick and to the point. Nearly every unit in the game has a special ability, from Tandis' sweep attack that hits all adjacent enemies to the Stalker's deadly maul, which hits over and over again until dodged.

Your sovereign can cast spells to help your forces out. A quick heal or weak summoned skeleton might give your armies the edge in the early game, but later on calling down devastating blizzards or walls of living flame can practically win battles by themselves.

SAVING THE WORLD

The Sorcerer King is trying to destroy the shards. Stop him, or it's the literal end of the world.

Each shard destroyed by the Sorcerer King's forces pushes the Doomsday Counter forward. If it fills up, it's game over.

Complete quests in benevolent ways to lower the Doomsday Counter and delay the Sorcerer King's victory, and defend the shards as best you can to keep the assault at bay.

FACING THE SORCERER KING

There is only one way to win in Sorcerer King: You must defeat him in battle. Naturally, it's easier said than done.

First, you must find his two lieutenants. Don't worry, you can't miss the enormous fire and ice demons roaming the landscape. Bringing lots of friends and a full mana bank to any confrontation with the lieutenants is highly recommended.

Once you've bested both lieutenants, you must fight your way to the heart of the Sorcerer King's domain. Even more friends and as much mana as you can possibly scrounge together are a good idea at this point.

CRAFTING

Crafting is critical in Sorcerer King. Killing monsters and completing quests gives you crafting materials, which you can turn into everything from basic chainmail to epic flaming swords.

Both heroes and regular units can use crafted items. A fully equipped unit can be several times more effective than a bare one.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Alemungula
boardgame.description:
From Mancala World:

Alemungula is a mancala game played by the Wetawit (formerly spelled Wetaweat) in Ethiopia, around the towns of Asosa and Beni Sangul, towards the Sudan border. Wetawit is an ethnic group in Ethiopia and Sudan. They speak Berta, a Nilo-Saharan language. The population of this group is about 248,000.

The game is played mainly by youngsters, though sometimes also by adults in their leisure time. It is closely related to Um el Bagara ("the cow game") which is played by the Baggara in northern Sudan. However, Alemungula offers bigger challenges because singletons may also be moved.

Alemungula was first described by the ethiopist Richard Pankhurst in 1971. The game was implemented by Arty Sandler for online play at igGameCenter on December 19, 2010.

Rules

Alemungula is played on a wooden board which consists of 2x5=10 holes known as tisiya alemungula ("alemungula wood"), while the holes are called ful alemungula. Play is begun with five stones in each hole.

At his turn, a player picks up all the contents of one of his holes and then distributes, one by one, the stones into the following holes, the direction depending on the hole chosen. Moves from either of a player's two left-hand holes are made in clockwise direction, moves from either of the player's two right-hand holes are made in an anti-clockwise direction, and moves from the center hole may be made in either direction. The move is finished after a single lap.

A singleton which is played into an empty hole of the opponent's side, that is either the last or the first hole of the opponent's row), may not be played back in the next move.

If the last stone is dropped in one of the opponent's holes and makes a two or a four, these stones are captured. Should one or more of the opponent's holes immediately preceding this on the line of play, also have been increased to two or four stones these will likewise be captured.

The captured stones are removed from the board and stored.

The game ends when a player has no legal move. Each player then captures the stones remaining on his side.

The winner is the player who captured the greater number of stones during the game. If both players captured the same number the game is a draw.

boardgame.name: Blood Before Richmond: Glendale & White Oak Swamp
boardgame.description:
The second title in the Blood Before Richmond series recreates the Battle of Glendale, and its artillery-only side-show, White Oak Swamp.

The Union host is heading for Malvern Hill, a superior defensive position that will allow them to escape destruction and encirclement. If Lee wants to achieve those aims, he needs to cut off that retreat at a place called Glendale, which requires the careful coordination of his generals. But, par for the course, only A.P. Hill and Longstreet seem capable of doing what they’re told: Ben Huger and his men are too busy moonlighting as lumberjacks, while Stonewall Jackson fights a pointless artillery duel at White Oak Swamp - when he’s not napping, anyway. Difficult terrain and fresh, high-quality Union brigades mean that the weary Confederates have their work cut out for them. The optional Galena Rule gives the Union command-control problems of their own to contend with.

Like other titles in the series, a modified 2d6 die roll determines which Confederate divisions activate on a given turn. Divisions that didn't pull there weight are less likely to show up than those that did most of the fighting. It's a simple, clever, and elegant way to recreate the difficulties that Lee had during the Seven Days.

Blood Before Richmond builds on the same "stacks of steps" combat system introduced in Tom Russell's Blood on the Alma (2012). Flipping a counter over when you take a hit just doesn't capture the feel of bloody infantry collisions or the horrifying impact of artillery fire. This system uses step counters stacked beneath an identifying counter to account for brutal attrition and devastating wipe-outs.

Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. 9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

boardgame.name: Isle of Coconuts
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:

The Isle of Coconuts is a beautiful place with lush palm trees and teams of Monkeys jumping from tree to tree competing for delicious coconuts. Roll the dice and count your chances to become the biggest team on the palm tree or be smart enough to stay away - either way, you win coconuts. Let your team be the first to gather 10 coconut tokens to win the game.

What They'll Learn

Quick Addition - Each turn, players add up the dice one of three ways to decide where to place Monkeys on palm tree fronds.

Risk vs. Reward - Players pick the palm trees where they can build the biggest team of Monkeys. Stay away from trees where there could be an all-way tie or where you might end up being the smallest team when all the palm tree fronds are full.

boardgame.name: JunkWars
boardgame.description:
Junkwars is a card game set in a post-apocalyptic future.
Each player will have to choose one of the Factions, represented by their own unique deck, fighting for the control over Neworld, the last city on Earth.

The strategy is based upon:
-the positioning of units on the table (each unit is represented by a unique card,and can be deployed on three different battle lines)
-the allocation of resources: the game has 2 main resources, Matter and Spirit. Matter is used for direct attacks while Spirit is used to unlock powers.

The objective of the game is to take down the enemy Overlord. This is the most powerful unit of the deck and is no deployed at the beginning of the game. In order to force the opponent to deploy his Overlord, the player must inflict consistent damages to the opponent's units. Doing so, the opponent will have access to buffs and, at the end, he will have to deploy his Overlord on the table, making it vulnerable to attacks.

boardgame.name: Ringmaster
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Ringmaster is a niche genre game that simulates showy professional wrestling. The rules primarily are intended to allow the creation of a variety of wrestlers, from Megastar to Monster Heel, and the simulation of a variety of acrobatic wrestling maneuvers. Characters have Background, Attributes, Height, Weight, and Traits (derived attributes). Characters may also have Merits (advantages) and/or Flaws (disadvantages). Characters track Prestige through several ranks.

Wrestling (combat) in the game involves a series of exchanges of Maneuvers. The game presents a lengthy list of Maneuvers and descriptions. Wrestling primarily involves Attribute Checks using D100 against Attribute, attempting to "roll under" the target. An unmodified roll of 01-05 is an Ace while 96-00 is a Botch. The wrestling rules, forming the obvious focus of the entire game, can become quite complex as character utilize a chain of maneuvers with various outcomes.

The campaign portion of the game deals primarily with rankings, earnings, skills development, managers, and other aspects of a typical wrestler's daily life.

boardgame.name: The Buildings
boardgame.description:
The Buildings uses the gameplay found in Sky Scrapers, but creates new goals for new playing areas.

In each game, you start with pieces of the two players on the game board. Each turn, a player moves one of their own stacks a number of spaces equal to the height of the stack, stacking it onto of another stack. A stack is owned by the player whose piece is on top.

In the original Sky Scrapers game, included in this set, whoever has the most stacks that contain at least four pieces wins the game. A different game board crowns the player who has created the tallest stack. A third game board gives the win to whoever controls more of the six inner spaces on the game board.

boardgame.name: e-SOLO-e
Japanesque (和風絵揃)
Moon-Sun-Angel
Nekoten (ねこの天使)
絵揃
boardgame.description:
Moon-Sun-Angel includes sixteen cubes, eight each in two colors, with each cube featuring the moon, sun and angel on three sides and having blank faces on the other three. Players takes turns placing one cube in the playing area, either on the game board or on another cube.

If a player can create a row of four cubes that feature the same symbol or color, that player wins. Alternately, a player can create two rows of three cubes to win.

After a successful launch at the Tokyo Game Market in November 2015, a new edition was produced in January 2016 under the name e-SOLO-e (絵揃), which is a Japanese word that means "match symbols". Three editions were produced, Spiritual (a copy of the original Moon-Sun_Angel edition), Japanesque (和風絵揃), and Cat World (Nekoten ねこの天使). The last had artwork by Shukoko Yamamoto based on her artwork of Cat Angels.

boardgame.name: Bushi Tanto
boardgame.description:
Formerly Bushido, the Card Game.

A Samurai push-your-luck, set collection game for 2-5 players. Take to the Dojo and Roll dice, allocating them to the available Virtues. Learn enough Virtues of the Bushido Code to impress one of the Daimyo in order to win!

For twelve years the Province of Tosa has been blessed with peace and prosperity. Peace and prosperity that has been won through valiant battle and sacrifice. That has left Tosa with little army, yet still what remains defends the earned prosperity. Until sea-faring invaders lay siege to Kochi, a capital port for Tosa, and threatens this lasting peace. With the invaders not willing to negotiate; the Shogun orders his many Daimyo to travel Tosa in search of recruits to train in order to bolster the dwindling ranks of Samurai for the inevitable military confrontation.

Bushi Tanto is an interesting blend of push-your-luck and strategy. Each roll of the die will leave you with a decision, collect virtues that are needed to win, or activate Daimyo abilities to alter the game to your advantage. Either decision, however small, will ultimately lead to your victory or failure.

Bushi Tanto doesn't lack interactive gameplay. Many of the Virtue cards dynamically alter the game when collected. Focus tokens can force a player to reroll any die result at any time - and each of the Daimyo has a special ability to help or hinder training!

Compete as samurai potentials to be the first player recruited!

boardgame.name: RIP: Roleplaying the Infinite Possibilities
boardgame.description:
User summary:

RIP is a generic, universal system that can be adapted to almost any genre of traditional role-playing. The game is a rules-light structure that assumes a significant amount of Game Master input and development in a specific genre before it will support a campaign.

Characters are generated from a Character Point pool which are used to buy Attributes, Skills, and Background Options. A "normal human being" can be built for five points; characters start with about 20 points. Characters have Attributes (Strength, Endurance, Agility, Awareness, Willpower, ans Social. Attributes have Levels ranging from -2 to +2 with 0 being average. Special Attributes may be added to support specific genres. Skills represent learned or natural abilities; Skills have a Level ranging from 0 to 4. Background Options give characters a diverse range of possible benefits.

boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

Syndicate is a fast-paced, simple role playing game of the near future. Life in near future is cheap and short, and players must always be careful and on the edge. Syndicate was originally meant for realistic cinematic campaigns, but is good for any campaign with need for fast realistic system. Cinematic does not mean that players cannot die. They die, and very easily. Cinematic in Syndicate means that players can make feats typical to action movies and is not hit as easily as common folk, making the game session more like action movies than realistic real-life stories.

User summary:

Syndicate V: The Corporate Future is a Cyberpunk setting developed around the RIP game system. Prior editions of the setting were similar.

boardgame.name: Hvězdokupy: Hra plná hvězd
boardgame.description:
Hvězdokupy: Hra plná hvězd (Czech for "Star Clusters: A Game Full of Stars") is an abstract logical game for 2 to 6 players. The players of this game become astronomers trying to find a given constellation. The goal is to be the first player to find the given constellation.

The game is played on a shared 10x10 grid board, which represents the night sky. Each player is assigned a unique constellation to look for on the board. During the game, players take turns to place stars on the grid based on dice rolls. The number rolled on the dice shows with how many stars the currently placed star must neighbour. The dice is 8-sided and each number is part of a pair, so the player may choose between 2 different results. The first player to find/construct their given constellation among the stars wins the game. Shared victories are possible.

A remarkable feature of the game is that the major game pieces glow in the dark, making the game suitable for playing at night, which contributes to its theme.

boardgame.name: RORPS: Really Odd Role Playing System
boardgame.description:
User summary:

RORPS is a comedy game system that is intended as a playable satire. The mechanics are usable, if bizarre. The 2nd Edition of the game is apparently the first actual edition; the 2nd Edition title appears to have been used to make the system seem more credible. The game uses idiosyncratic language to refer to standard role-playing terms: CowMaster (Game Master), Ouch Points (Hit Points), Poopy Stuffs (Disadvantages), and Stuff Points (Experience Points) are samples.

Characters select a Race and then generate Traits (Abilities) - the game has four: Buffness, Breath, Hair Color, and Bowel Control. Characters next select Skills and Poopy Stuffs (disadvantages). The game presents a resolution mechanic (because "all games have rules") of rolling a dice pool against a Difficult Check Number. The number of dice in the pool is determined by the Attribute being tested. Combat works in a similar manner; successful hits deliver Ouch Points. The game concludes with "Pointless Rules" (movement rates, throwing ranges, etc.) to keep "some roleplayers" happy. One of the pointless rules presents a (slightly) more complex combat system.

This month’s installment of Unearthed Arcana features a number of new character options ideal for an Underdark campaign.
Two new fighting styles for fighters, paladins, and rangers focus on close-quarters combat, whether defending allies or unleashing deadly ranged attacks at nearby foes. Both styles are handy for dungeon delving and for battles in the confined environments of the Underdark.

boardgame.name: Rules of Thumb
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The basic role-playing approach in Rules of Thumb is to resolve all situations through collaborative narration. If this becomes impossible or undesirable, the Narrator (Game Master) will call for a Task Resolution. The Narrator determines a Base Difficulty, applicable modifiers are applied, and the player rolls (usually) 2d10 and compares the result. The rules provide substitute statistics if other dice types are desired ("if players prefer other types of dice").

Characters have Traits and Attributes, but generally character creation is free-form with narrative tags providing characterization and capability. Combat is slightly more detailed in terms of difficulties.

The system as presented is utilized with a post-apocalyptic setting. However, the rules would be usable with any traditional genre.

boardgame.name: Cobrat Racebook
boardgame.description:
From the description:

The cobrat are reptilian creatures divided into three subspecies: high cobrat, low cobrat and troglodytes. High cobrat have snakelike bodies between 9-12 foot long and about 18 inches in diameter. They stand between 6 and 7 feet tall, with the rest of their body trailing behind them as they walk. They have thin, but powerful legs and spindly arms that end in four long digits. High cobrat are covered in scales ranging in color from dark green (almost black) to a light tan.

Low cobrat are hulking humanoids that stand 5 feet tall. Their bodies are heavily muscled and powerful. They have scales and their coloration is similar to that of the high cobrat. They look like “lizard men” from other fantasy games.

Troglodytes look very similar to low cobrat. However, they are closer to 8 feet tall and even more powerful. Their scales grow quickly and they are continuously shedding old scales. Often the scales grow too fast and individual scales crowd one another causing them to be crooked.

User summary:

The book provides a single race for use with the Runebearer game.

As the area became more settled, the need for the post decreased and it was abandoned.

A number of months ago, a small bandit gang took up residence in the post. They traveled the land, attacking merchants and raiding small villages and farmsteads. After their raids, they fled to this place, counting on its remote location to keep them hidden. In the case of attack, the bandits used the tower to give them warning and time to prepare a defense or flee.

boardgame.name: s3 (Version 1.0)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Characters have Stats (Attributes) that are assigned a Stat Score. The five Stats are Strength, Agility, Health, Intelligence Quotient, Intuition, and Allure. Stat Scores are recorded as "Dice"; an average human Stat Score is D10; "First Class" ability is D16, and so forth--from D2 to D20 by each even number step. The Stat Score is actually determined by rolling 2D5 and doubling the number rolled and converting this to a "Dice". Characters then purchase Skills, each of which has an associated Stat (unfortunately named, and not to be confused with the earlier Stats). The Skill Stat determines modifiers that will be applied when that Skill is used. Combat is handled like a Skill.

boardgame.name: s3 (Version 1.1)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

s3 Version 1.1 presents a re-written and cleaned-up set of generic, universal rules. Character creations beings with conceptualization and then follows to Stat (Attributes) and Stat Score generation. Stats include Strength, Agility, Health, Intelligence Quotient, Intuition, Allure, and Essence. Stat Scores are randomly generated but are recorded as a "Dice", ranging from D2 to D10 at every even step; D10 is considered average, Near Perfect is considered D18. Characters next select Skills. Skills have a number called Level, running from 1-20.

Action resolution matches a dice roll with modifier against a Target Number. The die used is determined by the base Stat, the roll is modified by the Skill Level.

boardgame.name: Loop Inc.: Expansion Cards
boardgame.description:
This Limited Edition expansion adds 14 new cards to the game.

Anomalies (4 cards)
Every time you go back in time, anomalies are added to the game. More anomalies means more variability!

Future (5 cards)
Instead of going back in time, you have the option of going into the future. Futures add a bit more complexity to the game, as each future trip allows you to take a bonus action. If you play the future right, you can unlock some fantastic combinations!

Office (5 cards)
The Office action cards replace the simple Trash action cards in the game. Now, instead of merely removing components in order prevent the loss of points, you can time your actions to gain points.

These cards were included for free for all backers of Loop Inc. on Kickstarter. However, these extras are available for purchase separately. None are Kickstarter-exclusive.

boardgame.name: Loop Inc.: Expansion Tiles
boardgame.description:
This Limited Edition expansion adds 16 tiles to the game.

Performance Goals (7 tiles)
At the beginning of the game, each player receives one randomly dealt tile as a secret goal, hidden from the other players. Players who have fulfilled the goal listed on their tile score bonus points at the end of the game.

Waste Memo (5 tiles)
At the beginning of the game, one Waste Memo tile is chosen at random. During the game, component penalties no longer simply count as -1 points, but rather carry the penalties indicated on the tile. Components are left face-up in the penalty area to prevent confusion.

Butterfly Effect (4 tiles)
After shuffling these tiles, they are placed, one by one, face down above trip cards, starting with the trip cards that take travelers the furthest back in time. One tile is placed for each player in the game (i.e. in a 3-player game, the three furthest-back trip cards will each have one Butterfly Effect tile placed face-down above them). When that trip card is visited, the player picks up the tile and places it face up above any trip card later in the timeline. No trip card may have more than one tile placed above it. A face-up tile affects both trips on a trip card, and rewards or subtracts points at the end of the game.

These tiles were included for free for all backers of Loop Inc. on Kickstarter. However, these extras are available for purchase separately. None are Kickstarter-exclusive.

boardgame.name: Emporion
boardgame.description:
The ancient Greeks from Phocaea urgently want to expand their domains. They are sailing for the Iberian peninsula to establish a permanent trading spot. In a tiny island close to the northern east coast, the newcomers will found Emporion, the first great Greek settlement on the peninsula. From there, they will try to increase their fame and fortune by commanding expeditions, trading valuable goods with Athens, competing to win the favor of Gods, and promoting the Hellenistic culture throughout the Iberian lands.

In more detail, in Emporion, players buy cards and place them in their play areas. These cards help players to improve their armies, build spectacular and diverse constructions, trade goods, explore new lands, and perform cultural events.

boardgame.name: Pralaya
王国沉没
boardgame.description:
Long ago, there was an island nation in the southern sea that enjoyed a great period of cultural prosperity. Surrounded by natural beauty and gifted with tremendous intellect, the island's residents believed their peaceful lifestyle would go on for all time. But one morning, a fearsome demon broke free and began to drag the island into the depths of the sea. With the end growing near, the king ordered his most loyal retainers to gather as much of the nation's knowledge and as many of the island's treasures as they could, and flee to the northern lands.

In Pralaya, your goal is to secure island relics and people and evacuate them from the sinking island. The more you evacuate, the higher you score. But don't press your luck too much or you'll risk valuable points for saving yourself.

Will you collect the most valuable relics, coins, and buy your safe passage from the island before it sinks into the deep?

遥か昔、南海には美しい島が存在しました。しかし恐るべき悪魔が島を海に沈め始めたのです。島が沈む前に多くの宝を集め北の地に脱出しましょう！

島の遺物と残された命を集め、北の地へ脱出する事が目的です。より多くを集めた人が勝利しますが、島が完全に沈む前に脱出しなければ命を落としてしまいます。遺物を効率よく集める事はもちろん、脱出のタイミングを見極める事も重要となります。なお、逃げ遅れたとしても集めた遺物だけでも事前に船で送り出していた場合、その功績は評価されるので必ず負けるわけではありません。新しいタイプの戦略型チキンレースです。

boardgame.name: Where's Wally? The Board Game
boardgame.description: Finding Wally is never child's play but it's even trickier when there's a board made up of four movable sections and a ticking timer to battle against! If you know a fan of the red and white jumper-wearing character, then they'll love the chance to show their stripes in this exciting fast and furious search and find game where they'll say goodbye to school holiday boredom and so long to rainy day blues. Great for girls and boys alike aged seven upwards (and fun-loving grown-ups too!), the Where's Wally? Board Game is a race against time where being eagle-eyed and speedy is a winning combination! Players must find the picture on the board which matches the picture on their card. It might sound simple but try doing that when the sections of the board have been rearranged and there's a constant tick telling you that time is running out. The aim of the game is to be the fastest player to find and cover Where's Wally? pictures on the board with a Wally token. The next player tries to do the same and so the game continues until the timer stops. A card with a number '2' on it means double the challenge - you have to match the picture on your card to the picture on the board twice before play moves on. And if you collect a card with an 'R' on it, the direction of play is reversed and the four sections of the Where's Wally? board must be rearranged too. Simply super stripy fun for Where's Wally? fans who like a challenge!

boardgame.name: The Secrets of the Divine: Death, Justice, Healing, & Madness
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Come Explore the Mysteries of Heaven and Earth!

A modular presentation of specific churches that you can easily place in nearly any campaign setting; including information on who these deities are, who worships them, quotes, prayers, special orders to help suspend the disbelief of Players and Game Masters alike.

You will also find out how each church interacts with society, governments, and the everyday lives of folks from all walks of life, but with a primary focus on adventurers so that those interactions can be role-played seamlessly. It also includes local mythology related to the deity making the religion have an actual impact upon campaigns; Manifestations of the deity so you can show through both subtle omens and blessings or the wrath of the gods as well. Each church also gives information on religious holidays to spice up the passage of time in a campaign.

Along with a host of new divine archetypes, domain feats, and other new custom game mechanics to bring The Secrets of the Divine to life!

This product contains:

Our Mother of Many Ways a chaotic church dedicated to genius & madness along with wine & hedonism.
Our Queen of Wisdom and Mercy a church for healers, peacemakers, and imprisoning foes.
Our Reaper of Death and Rebirth a dour deity of the dead, reincarnation, and killing immortals.
Our Steely Eyed-Judge a lawful church filled with those who seek truth, justice, and retribution.


Its new game mechanics include

Domain Feats for use with specific Domain powers, to make them even more useful and fun.
Slayer Talents for those who wish to take their foes alive.
Joyous Fellowship (Paladin Archetype) become a holy warrior filled with religious euphoria & bliss from which you gain special powers all while playing a hedonistic paladin.
Queen’s Men (Paladin Archetype) Enjoy the role of a holy bodyguard and dedicate yourself to the protection of a singular worthy individual, rather promoting the cause of righteousness in the world at large.
Harmonious Fist (War Preist Archetype) Leave behind lethal weapons and chose instead to defend yourself, while imprisoning your foes even when you are far away from civilization.
Ruiners (Fighter Archetype) Seek out and curse immortal and undying foes with curses the like of which will force them to seek their own deaths rather than suffer at your hands.
Phoenix-Child (Universal Archetype) Return from beyond the grave in a reincarnated form, so that you can seek redemption, and transform into a phoenix to see it done.
Thief-Taker (Slayer Archetype) bring’em back alive to face justice, or hunt down stolen goods for anyone who can afford your services.

boardgame.name: Drilled Teamwork Feat
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Bring new tactical options to your game with the Drilled Teamwork Feat, an option that allows you to train others for specific functions and pass on feat related bonuses to them!

While a plethora of options exist to represent almost any kind of combatant in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game, the fall-back method of representing the concept of a group of adventurers well-trained to work together in combat with one another is by having characters take various Teamwork feats. While this can be a viable option, many players may be reticent to permanently choose a teamwork feat that is really only useful some of the time. It also doesn’t represent as well the idea that a seasoned group of veteran adventurers could spend time preparing themselves for coming combat with a known threat (be it giants from the mountains, flying dragons, etc.). Just as a wizard with forewarning can have “just the right spell” for a given circumstances, the Drilled Teamwork feat presented here offers more martial characters a viable option for preparing for combat together.

Take your teamwork to the next level... Drilled Teamwork Feats in Sidebar #11 from Fat Goblin Games!
